coredata.dc:title: Construction of a new magnetic coordination polymer through an unusual Fe-mediated in situ redox reaction

coredata.dc:description: A new iron(II) coordination polymer, namely [Fe(Hmna)2] n (1; H2 mna = 2-mercaptonicotinic acid), has been synthesized under hydrothermal condition through an unusual Fe-mediated in situ redox reaction. Complex 1 was characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and elemental analyses as well as thermogravimetric analysis. 1 generally exhibits one-dimensional linear structures bridged through the sulfur and oxygen donors of organic ligand, which are further attached into a three-dimensional supramolecular structure via intermolecular hydrogen bond interactions. The construction of compound 1 involved an unusual in situ Fe(III)/Fe(II) redox reaction, which was confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. In addition, magnetic measurements for 1 indicated the presence of overall antiferromagnetic interactions within structure.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) The coordination environment of Fe(II) in complex 1, where displacement ellipsoids are drawn at the 50% probability level; (b) View of the one-dimensional linear structure bridged by sulfur and oxygen atoms along the c axis; (c) View of 1 along the a axis. All hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity. Gray, C; blue, N; red, O; yellow, S; brown, Fe. Symmetry codes: a = 1 + x, y, z; b = 1−x, −y, 1−z; c = 2−x, −y, 1−z.
Perspective view of the three-dimensional packing diagram of complex 1 along the a axis. Gray, C; blue, N; red, O; white, H; yellow, S; brown, Fe.
X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) of Fe 2p region for compound 1, where the arrow indicates the satellite peak for iron(II).
Plots of the temperature dependence of χ M (circles) and χ M T (rhombuses) for 1 at 5 kOe.
Coordination and chelation mode of the Hmna ligand in 1.
Crystallographic and data collection parameters for complex 1.
Selected bond lengths (Å) and bond angles (°) for 1.

head.ce:title: Construction of a new magnetic coordination polymer through an unusual Fe-mediated in situ redox reaction

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, China University of Mining and Technology, Beijing 100083, China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering
China University of Mining and Technology

ce:affiliation.ce:label: b
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: State Key Laboratory of Structural Chemistry, Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Fuzhou 350002, China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: State Key Laboratory of Structural Chemistry
Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A new iron(II) coordination polymer, namely [Fe(Hmna)2] n (1; H2 mna = 2-mercaptonicotinic acid), has been synthesized under hydrothermal condition through an unusual Fe-mediated in situ redox reaction. Complex 1 was characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and elemental analyses as well as thermogravimetric analysis. 1 generally exhibits one-dimensional linear structures bridged through the sulfur and oxygen donors of organic ligand, which are further attached into a three-dimensional supramolecular structure via intermolecular hydrogen bond interactions. The construction of compound 1 involved an unusual in situ Fe(III)/Fe(II) redox reaction, which was confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. In addition, magnetic measurements for 1 indicated the presence of overall antiferromagnetic interactions within structure.

ce:section.ce:para: Compared to the tremendous amount of multitopic carboxylate and/or nitrogen-containing ligands-based coordination polymers, the chemistry of coordination polymers constructed by organic sulfur-containing heterocycles has been developed relatively faintly [1–4]. However, the metal-sulfur coordination polymers possess potential and excellent properties in terms of electronic, magnetic and conductive materials [5]. Furthermore, these compounds have great appeal for biologists because many metalloenzymes consist of metal-sulfur complexes.

The in situ metal/ligand synthesis has been proved to be a new avenue to the preparation of functional materials and the discovery of new reactions [5–7]. For sulfur-containing heterocyclic ligands, these reactions generally include in situ disulfide reactions, in situ cleavage of CS bond and in situ thiol-S atom reactions [5]. Several new crystal structures have been reported under the strategy of in situ metal/ligand synthesis by us [8–10]. For example, a new magnetic Mn(II) coordination polymer with unusual hxg topology was constructed through in situ formation of disulfide reaction, where 6-mercaptonicotinic acid was converted into 6,6′-dimercaptodinicotinate ligand with axial chirality [8]. Under the similar in situ disulfide reaction, we also synthesized another magnetic coordination polymer containing unprecedented [Ni9S10] cluster very recently [9]. In addition, we reported the successful fabrication of a two-dimensional mesh network via in situ cleavage and coupling of CS bond [10]. Although numerous coordination polymers with interesting architectures have been constructed by in situ metal/ligand reactions so far, the examples of in situ redox reactions usually involve Cu(I)/Cu(II) ions [5–7]. Meanwhile, the in situ Fe(III)/Fe(II) redox reactions have also been found in some coordination structures [11–13]. However, coordination polymers assembled and mediated by Fe(III)/Fe(II) in situ redox reactions are very limited [5–7].

Recently, two sulfur-containing hetercyclic ligands, viz. 2-mercaptonicotinic acid and 6-mercaptonicotinic acid (Scheme 1 ), have attracted our attention for the fabrication of new coordination materials. By the assembly with Mn(II), Ni(II), Zn(II) and Cd(II) as well as lanthanide ions, we have synthesized a series of new coordination polymers with intriguing properties [8–10,14–16]. Herein, we report the synthesis and crystal structure of a new complex [Fe(Hmna)2] n (1; H2 mna = 2-mercaptonicotinic acid) based on 2-mercaptonicotinic acid through an unusual Fe-mediated in situ redox reaction. The complex 1 displays one-dimensional chain-like construction by iron-sulfur and iron-oxygen coordination bonds, and further form three-dimensional supermolecular structures via intermolecular hydrogen bonds. Furthermore, the involved in situ redox reaction mediated by Fe(III)/Fe(II) has been discussed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Moreover, the magnetic properties have been investigated in detail in the present contribution.

All chemicals were of AR grade commercially available and directly used without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H and N were carried out with a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded in the range of 4000–400 cm−1 on a Perkin-Elemer Specture-one FTIR instrument with KBr pellet. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was conducted on an X’ Pert Pro MPD X-ray diffractometer (PANalytical B.V.) using CuKα radiation in the ambient environment, whereas the calculated pattern of 1 was simulated using PowerCell software. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on an HCT-2 Thermal Analyzer (Beijing Henven Scientific Instrument Company, China) with a heating rate of 10 °C · min−1 under nitrogen atmosphere. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi, USA) was used to collect the XPS spectrum of Fe 2p. A Quantum Design MPMS model-XL magnetometer was used for the magnetic measurements of 1.

[Fe(Hmna)
2
]
n
(1). A mixture of Fe2O3 (0.125 mmol, 0.0200 g), 2-mercaptonicotinic acid (0.50 mmol, 0.0776 g) and 10 mL H2O was stirred in air for 30 min and then sealed in 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. After being heated at 180 °C for 96 h, the mixture was cooled down slowly to room temperature over 48 h. Stick-like and dark red crystals were obtained in 13% yield based on Fe. Anal. Calcd. for FeC12H8O4N2S2 (%): C, 39.58; H, 2.21; N, 7.69. Found: C, 39.36; H, 2.15; N, 7.56.

Crystal data of 1 was collected on a Mercury70 diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromatic MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K. Empirical absorption corrections were applied with SADABS program. The structure was solved by direct methods with SHELXTL package [17,18]. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were generated with idealized geometries and treated as riding. The structure was refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques. The crystallographic data and other pertinent information are summarized in Table 1 , while the selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table 2 .

Single crystal X-ray diffraction revealed that complex 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group of P21/n and its chemical formula can be expressed as [Fe(Hmna)2] n (H2 mna = 2-mercaptonicotinic acid). Complex 1 could be best described as a one-dimensional linear structure with iron-sulfur skeleton, which further forms a three-dimensional supermolecular construction via intermolecular hydrogen bond interactions.

The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one Hmna ligand and one Fe(II) ion. As depicted in Fig. 1 a, the Fe atom is inversion center-related and is six-coordinated by two oxygen atoms of the carboxylic groups and four sulfur atoms from different Hmna ligands. Four mercapto sulfur atoms form the equatorial plane, while the axial positions are filled by two carboxylic oxygen atoms. This type of coordination mode is rarely documented in previous works based on the Cambridge Structural Database [19–21]. The FeO distance is 1.9888(14) Å, while the FeS bond length falls in the range of 2.5222(9)–2.6675(10) Å. The Hmna ligand adopts a μ 2-η 2:η 1-coordination mode and shows a six-membered chelating ring (Scheme 2 ), and this particular type of chelating ring is only previously reported by the Liaw and Christou groups [22,23].

To further investigate the chemical structure of 1, Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrum was collected. As displayed in Fig. S1, the absorption band appearing at 3072 cm−1 can be attributed to the stretching vibration of ArH bond. The absence of absorption bands around 1700 and 2550 cm−1 is suggestive of the deprotonated of carboxylate group and mercapto group of the organic ligand. Accordingly, the intense absorption peaks at 1572 and 1374 cm−1 can be assigned to asymmetry stretching and symmetry stretching vibrations of carboxylic group (COO−), respectively. The larger separation value of ν(COO−) (i.e. 198 cm−1) indicates that the carboxylic group within the ligand adopts as unidentate coordination mode, in accordance with the results from single crystal X-ray diffraction [24]. All of the other FTIR absorption bands are in agreement with the single crystal structure. In addition, the powder X-ray diffraction (Fig. S2) was also conducted to check the purity of 1.

To investigate the thermal stability of compound 1, thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was carried out in the temperature range of 30–1000 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere using polycrystalline samples. As depicted in Fig. 3 , compound 1 remains stable until about 380 °C, and then the TG curve undergoes considerable of weight loss, which is attributed to the decomposition of organic ligand and the collapse of framework.

In consideration of the charge balance and the crystal structure of 1, the valence of iron ions within the product seems to be divalent, suggesting that the iron ions experienced a valence alternation, i.e. from the initial Fe(III) in the reactant to Fe(II) in 1. In order to validate our hypothesis, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out in Fe 2p region for compound 1. As depicted in Fig. 4 , the XPS spectrum exhibits the Fe 2p 1/2 and 2p 3/2 peaks as well as a clear satellite peak between them, centered at 722.9, 709.1 and 712.9 eV, respectively. These characteristics are well consistent with Fe(II) compounds [25–28]. Therefore, the iron valence state is divalent in 1 obtained from Fe2O3 and H2 mna, indicative of the presence of an in situ redox reaction during the synthetic process. Furthermore, it is assumed that the organic ligand (H2 mna) plays the roles of not only linkers but also reducing reagents, as suggested by previous reports [29,30]. To the best of our knowledge, the in situ redox metal/ligand reactions for the fabrication of coordination polymers have been mainly limited to copper ions, while the in situ redox metal/ligand reactions involving iron ions are very rare [5–7].

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility of 1 was studied using polycrystalline sample under an applied field of 5 kOe in the temperature range of 2–300 K. The magnetic properties of 1 are illustrated as χ M and χ M T versus T plots as displayed in Fig. 5 . The χ M T value at 300 K is calculated to be 3.65 emu K mol−1, which is corresponding to the expected theoretical value for the high-spin form of Fe(II) [31]. Upon cooling from room temperature to 2 K, the χ M T value generally remains constant in the temperature range of 300–30 K, and then declines rapidly with the further decrease in temperature, reaching 1.42 emu K mol−1 at 2 K. Meanwhile, the χ M value increases from 0.012 to 0.710 emu mol−1. In addition, when applying the Curie-Weiss law, the Curie constant (C) and Weiss constant (θ) can be calculated to be 3.65 emu K mol−1 and −1.33 K, respectively. The effective magnetic moment calculated to be 5.4 μ B, which is larger than the spin-only value of 4.90 μ B for S = 2 and g = 2. The negative θ value indicates the presence of weakly antiferromagnetic interactions within the sulfur-bridging iron(II) molecular chain [32]. The magnetic data is fitted with the S = 2 chain model by Eq. (1), where u = coth(JS(S+1)/KT)−KT/JS(S+1). The best fitting gives J = −0.36 cm−1, g = 2.23 and R = 8.5 × 10−3. The small negative J value also suggests the presence of weak antiferromagnetic interactions among the Fe(II) ions in the chain.

In summary, a coordination polymer [Fe(Hmna)2] n (1; H2 mna = 2-mercaptonicotinic acid) has been hydrothermally synthesized through an unusual in situ Fe(III)/Fe(II) redox reaction. Single crystal X-ray diffraction disclosed that compound 1 exhibits a one-dimensional chain-like structure bridged by Fe(II) ion and sulfur, and further forms three-dimensional supramolecular construction via hydrogen bond interactions. Its chemical structure has been further confirmed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and elemental analyses. As suggested by charge balance calculations and further confirmed by XPS analysis, the formation of compound 1 involved an unusual Fe-mediated in situ redox reaction. Furthermore, magnetic measurements indicated that there exist weakly overall antiferromagnetic interactions within the structure.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: This work was supported by the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (2017QH01).
